data.title: Possible to use .es6 file extension?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: OSX 10.10

Is it possible to use the .es6 file extension, and still have the editor enable intellisense appropriately? For instance, I have some projects that use the ".es6" extension, and keywords like "module" have red lines under them, and the file isn't processed in the same way that a .js file is. Renaming the file to .js fixes the issues (but isn't always an option, due to internal project reasons).

data.title: Linux: fs.writeFile() can result in empty reads for external watchers

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11 Commit f291f4ad600767626b24a4b15816b04bee9a3049 - OS Version: Linux 4.2.0-34-generic #39~14.04.1 (Ubuntu) Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open known good partial (dust template), e.g, the menuItem.toggle.dust.emacs attached 2. Add and delete a space, then save. 3. Re-run dust rendering The output will be missing several elements. Given the dust template I'm using, I believe it may be a failure in the eq test. _BUT_ I know this isn't a Dust.js problem because it works if I save it from emacs: Steps to fix: 1. Open partial saved above, e.g., the menuItem.toggle.dust.code attached, in a good editor, e.g., emacs. 2. Add and delete a space, then save 3. Re-run dust rendering. The output will be as expected. I was able to toggle back & forth between the two editors and consistently reproduce the results. What emacs saved worked fine. What code saved _did not_. I've attached the two partials. I'm guessing it's a unicode/text format issue. None of my diff tools showed any difference, but CLEARLY dust.js is treating one differently from the other. [menuItem.toggle.dust.zip](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/192799/menuItem.toggle.dust.zip) FWIW, here is the template in those attached files: ``` dust {@eq key=widget value="true"} {:else}
{text}
{true.text}
{false.text}
{/eq} ```

data.title: Stuck in debug mode when getting error for prelaunch task.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.12-alpha
- OS Version: Windows10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Launch app and open any folder which has .ts, .less. and .JS files.
2. Make sure build tool Grunt should be configured for opened directory.
3. Verify Gruntfile.js should be placed in root directory or create manually.
4. configure tasks.json file from command palette for Grunt.
5. Verify task name in the generated tasks.json file. (in my case "build" and "test")
   {
   // See http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=733558
   // for the documentation about the tasks.json format
   "version": "0.1.0",
   "command": "grunt",
   "isShellCommand": true,
   "args": ["--no-color"],
   "showOutput": "always",
   "tasks": [
       {
           "taskName": "build",
           "args": [],
           "isBuildCommand": true,
           "isWatching": false,
           "problemMatcher": [
               "$lessCompile",
               "$tsc",
               "$jshint"
           ]
       },
       {
           "taskName": "test",
           "args": [],
           "isTestCommand": true
       }  
   ]
   }
6. Go to debug section and select Node option to generate launch.json.
7. Update launch.json property for "preLauchTask" and provide task name "build" or "test".
   "preLaunchTask": "build",
8. Select launch option and start debugging.
9. Debugging started with error message "The prelaunchTask "Build" terminated with exit code 99".
   ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/14094949/e604b618-f50f-11e5-9e2d-9afcc4897de9.png)

Actual:
1. On the error pop-up user is getting two options "Continue" and "Close" when user clicks on "Close" then debugging should be stopped (This is same behavior like in visual studio when we get build error it asks for continue or close) but I observed when user clicks on close then the error pop-up closed but application remain in debugging mode forever.
2. When user tries to terminate the debug session by clicking on Stop button then nothing is happening.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/14094824/c72715a2-f50e-11e5-9ea8-e34cfad258c3.png)

data.title: [c#] Syntax highlighter not recognizing strings
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: Windows 10.0.10586

The VSCode editor sometimes doesn't recognize strings in C# source files, leading it to highlight code as strings and other strings as code. Here's an example of what I mean:

![vscode-grammar](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9159214/14094590/b8c3bd8c-f525-11e5-8ecb-9ddcc714256f.PNG)

The source for the repro can be found here:

https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/blob/b55b8085528d0199bd14fb417d3b764e643b8533/src/System.Runtime.Extensions/tests/System/Runtime/Versioning/FrameworkName.cs

Since GitHub seems to be choking on this as well, I'll also be opening an issue in Atom's [C# grammar repo](https://github.com/atom/language-csharp), but I thought it would be good to let you guys know.

data.title: Clean changes dialog box is non-modal on Linux
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.12-alpha
- OS Version: Ubuntu 15.10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Initialize a git repo or clone an existing one
2. Modify a file
3. Go to Git tab and Clean changes

Actual:
Clicking clean more than once brings up more than one 'Are you sure' dialog. 
![linuxcleanchanges](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12900364/14089306/292e7b30-f4e9-11e5-9bc8-960f9c57fa1e.png)

Expected:
In Windows, only one dialog box is shown and clicking again just redirects to the already open one.

data.title: Calling workspace.rootPath gives undebuggable error
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: OSX

I am working on enhancing some functionality to vscode, PR will be coming and trying to call the following and I get the following error.

```
import {workspace} from 'vscode';
console.log(workspace.rootPath);
```

```
An unknown error occurred. Please consult the log for more details.
```

There is nothing more in the Crome dev console and also the shell window where I am running `./scripts/code.sh`.

What is the proper way to get get the root workspace path?  In an extension the call to `workspace.rootPath` works fine.

data.title: Color Themes do not recognize multi-line variable declarations in JavaScript
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: Windows 7 Ultimate N

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a JavaScript file (.js)
2. Enable the Dark+ color theme through the File > Preferences > Color Theme menu
3. Make a variable declaration, ending in a comma
4. On the next line, make a second variable declaration, ending in a semicolon.

Example: 

``` javascript
var a = 0, // This variable will be stylized
    b = 0; // This variable will be not be stylized
```

data.title: JSX file formatting modifies tag contents
Support for project subfolders with their own git repo
data.body:
My project has one root folder with a bunch of related projects in subfolders each with their own git rep attached.

In Xamarin Studio it shows each project/subfolder with a description of which branch each repo is on.. i.e. "master". So instantly I can see each project is its own repo and which branch they are currently set to.

I deliberately avoided git submodules for other reasons.

Is it possible for VSCode to support different subfolders each with their own git repo?

data.title: Suggest: Improve error message when debug a ts file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: OS X 10.10.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a ts file named `index.ts`
2. Press debug button, the error message is: 

```
Cannot launch program '/Users/abc/index.ts'; enabling source maps might help.
```
1. In `launch.json`, I enable `sourceMaps`, Press debug button, the error message is:

```
Cannot launch program '/Users/abc/index.ts'; setting the 'outDir' attribute might help.
```

So I tried to change `outDir`, But later on, I find that, it's not a problem of 'outDir', it's a problem of no source map generated, I forgot `--sourceMap` when `tsc`.

So I suggest the first error message like:

```
Cannot launch program '/Users/abc/index.ts'; enabling source maps might help;
and make sure the source map '/Users/abc/index.js.map' is already generated.
```

data.title: [package.json] `repository` field does not need to be an object
data.body:
- VSCode Version: `0.10.11`
- OS Version: `OS X 10.11.3`

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a valid `package.json` file
2. Add a `repository` field with the values `Microsoft/vscode` (or whatever repository)

It looks like VS Code is complaining about the `repository` field not being an object. This is not entirely correct as per the [documentation](https://docs.npmjs.com/files/package.json#repository).

> For GitHub, GitHub gist, Bitbucket, or GitLab repositories you can use the same shortcut syntax you use for npm install:
> 
> ```
> "repository": "npm/npm"
> 
> "repository": "gist:11081aaa281"
> 
> "repository": "bitbucket:example/repo"
> 
> "repository": "gitlab:another/repo"
> ```

![screen shot 2016-03-28 at 13 06 44](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1913805/14076895/2f0ef762-f4e6-11e5-9130-6b1bd9357e4b.png)

data.title: Cannot debug TypeScript file if source map is in a different directory
data.body:
It's currently not possible to debug a TypeScript file when the source map is stored in a different directory.

However, I feel it should be possible to debug TypeScript files even when the corresponding source maps are stored in a different directory.

- OS Version: Windows 10/64

Steps to Reproduce:

https://github.com/SetTrend/VSC-Debugger

data.title: Changes to file language and indentation type do not presit
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a file and change the language and/or indentation type.
2.  Close the window.
3. Reopen the window.

The file will be loaded again but it will have the default language and indentation type.

data.title: Sash double clicks
data.body:
Start implementing #4660.

The provided code defines a new event that is fired when a stash is double-clicked, and two usages of itthe first one on the spitted editor frontiers, and the second one on the bottom panel border. It is easier to review this PR commit per commit.

The capture below demonstrates the feature on the spitted editor:

![vscode-resize](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1730702/14068179/47de5f96-f47b-11e5-94c7-30ffc826a52d.gif)

I may want in implement the sidebar optimal sizing that originally motivated #4660, but I would like to have some guidance on the code structure:
- Is `IViewletView` the right place to implement an optional `getOptimalWidth` method? [edit: Ive chosen `IViewlet` instead]
- What is the best way to perform the HTML elements width measurement? [edit: Ive found `DOM.getTotalWidth` and `DOM.getRelativeLeft`]
- How do I get the current viewlet in `vs/workbench/layout.ts`? [edit: the [viewlet service](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/84a6e40d4356f747c8c3bc841d87d4edc254f7c4/src/vs/workbench/services/viewlet/common/viewletService.ts#L24)]
- Where and how should I write some tests?

Thank you in advance for considering this contribution :-)

data.title: editor.action.selectAll ctrl+a keybinding should only apply "when": "editorTextFocus"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: Linux Mint 17

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a node project vscode. (Note: project file includes app.js)
2. Click on app.js. --> File is open in editor.
3. Use Ctrl + A to select all text. --> Text in app.js highlighted.
4. Press Delete. 

Expect: All text in file to be deleted.
Actual: Are you sure you want to delete `app.js`?

Seems like a UX issue with context. It appears in step 3, the editor has the context; while in step 4, the explorer has context. 

In order to actually delete all of the text, I have to click in the editor window, select all text and press Delete.

data.title: Keyboard binding for `ctrl+pausebreak' is impossible
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: Microsoft Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a keyboard binding with `"key": "ctrl+pausebreak"`
2. Save file.
3. Observe that the command does not execute when the key combination is pressed.

For example, the following binding does not work:
`{ "key": "ctrl+pausebreak",
      "command": "workbench.action.tasks.terminate" },`

Bindings for `pausebreak` on its own and `shift+pausebreak` do appear to work. Additionally, the _define keybinding_ widget exhibits behaviour that is consistent with this bug.

`pausebreak` pressed on its own:

![2016-03-27 vs code ctrl pausebreak 1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6370145/14066807/8a0ccb90-f454-11e5-93e4-79d673d40c33.png)

`shift+pausebreak` pressed:

![2016-03-27 vs code ctrl pausebreak 2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6370145/14066808/8c93d99e-f454-11e5-97bd-5deca7c621f9.png)

`ctrl+pausebreak` pressed:

![2016-03-27 vs code ctrl pausebreak 3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6370145/14066809/8df9ee7c-f454-11e5-9618-6e91e2e703a8.png)
